text.title: Berlusconi resigns in bid to avert elections

main.p: The Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, today agreed to resign and form a new government to strengthen his struggling conservative coalition, a move that will avert fresh elections.

Mr Berlusconi's impending resignation, announced today by the foreign minister, Gianfranco Fini, would end the country's longest serving post-war government. But with one more year of his five-year term of office left, the move will allow Mr Berlusconi to escape without calling an immediate election, which polls show he would lose.

Mr Berlusconi had been under pressure to resign since his centre-right coalition suffered a crushing defeat in a regional vote held across Italy earlier this month. His government neared collapse after the Union of Christian Democrats, a small centrist party headed by Marco Follini, quit the cabinet on Friday. Mr Follini demanded that Mr Berlusconi form a fresh government with a new platform.

Mr Fini made today's announcement after a meeting of coalition leaders in Rome. He said that at the meeting, Mr Follini "renewed (his) commitment to a new Berlusconi government" and Mr Berlusconi made the "ensuing decision to hand in his resignation to the head of state".
Mr Berlusconi is set to meet with Italy's president, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, later in the day.

The move will allow Mr Berlusconi to return to office with a parliamentary majority that may see him through another year. Resigning and immediately forming a new government is a tactic that has been used often by Italian prime ministers to strengthen faltering coalitions. Mr Berlusconi had resisted the move, dismissing it as a remnant of Italy's messy political past.

Once the prime minister hands in a resignation, it is up to the president to decide whether to ask Mr Berlusconi, or another candidate, to form a new government; or to dissolve parliament and call early elections. However, if a political agreement has been reached among majority forces, the president is expected to go along with it.

Mr Berlusconi's coalition took power in 2001, and the prime minister hoped the government would become the first in post-war Italy to serve out the full five-year term. After the centre-right's collapse in the April 3-4 regional vote, Mr Berlusconi had proposed a cabinet reshuffle and a revised programme to relaunch the coalition ahead of the general election next year. The proposal was rejected by Mr Follini's party.
